awd_titl_txt: Defining the Role of Elastic Fibers in Tendon Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
Tendons are essential tissues that transfer mechanical forces between muscles and bones.  This allows movement of the body and increases stability. Collagen is the main component of tendon, and collagen is well-aligned with the tensile forces that tendons are subjected to during use.  However, other components of tendon also aid in its function. Of these other components, elastic fibers are known to affect how tendons respond to mechanical forces. When elastic fibers in tendon are damaged or degraded, chronic pain or injuries can develop. However, it remains unclear how elastic fibers contribute to the mechanical properties of tendon and how they respond to repetitive use. This project will address this important gap in knowledge by investigating the role of elastic fibers in tendon under a broad range of conditions. Information gained from this research will advance understanding of how tendons function under healthy conditions. This may eventually lead to improved strategies to treat or replace tendons that have damaged or degraded elastic fibers to restore function and reduce the burden associated with these conditions.  This project will also develop a workshop on novel 3D tissue imaging to broaden impact within local research communities as well as partner with a high school biomedical science program to provide unique educational opportunities to aspiring scientists/engineers.

The objective of this research is to define the role of elastic fibers in tendon mechanics. Elastic fibers are a structural constituent of the tendon extracellular matrix and are therefore necessary for its mechanical integrity. Despite the evidence demonstrating the importance of elastic fibers in maintaining healthy mechanical properties in tendon, the detailed contributions of elastic fibers in tendon mechanics are not yet understood. This research will determine how elastic fibers affect the mechanical function of tendon by comparing the base structure, composition, and mechanics of normal and elastin-null mouse tendons using an array of experiments including two-photon and transmission electron microscopy, biochemical assays, and mechanical testing. The role of elastic fibers in overuse-induced tendinopathy will be determined using fatigue testing and forced treadmill running using mice to induce damage, while testing of cultured tendon explants will inform potential effects of elastic fibers on mechanotransduction. In addition, enzymatic degradation of elastic fibers in tendon will be utilized to evaluate the distinct roles of elastic fibers within fascicles and within the interfascicular matrix. Conclusions from this work will advance understanding of composition-dependent mechanics in tendon and ultimately inform efforts to restore proper function in tendons with elastinopathic conditions or with degradation caused by overuse or age.  This work is co-funded by the Biomechanics & Mechanobiology and the Physiological Mechanisms & Biomechanics programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Tendons are essential tissues of the musculoskeletal system that transfer mechanical forces between muscles and bones to allow movement of the body and increase stability. While the majority of tendon is made up of aligned collagen that is well-suited for the tensile forces that tendons are subjected to during use, other components of tendon also aid in its function. This project addressed an important gap in knowledge by investigating the role of elastic fibers, a structural component of the extracellular matrix that includes a protein called elastin, in tendon under a broad range of conditions. The intellectual merit of this work centers on the advanced understanding of how elastin contributes to the mechanical properties of tendons and may lead to improved strategies to treat or replace tendons with damaged or degraded elastic fibers to restore function and reduce the public health burden associated with these conditions.

This study evaluated the quantity, structure, and mechanical contribution of elastin in functionally distinct tendons across different species. Tendons with an energy-storing function had more elastin than tendons with a positional function, and human tendon had at least twice the elastin content of other species. While distinctions in the organization of elastic fibers between fascicles and the interfascicular matrix were observed, differences in structural arrangement of elastin between species and tendon type were limited. Mechanical testing paired with elastin degradation was used to evaluate the contribution of elastin to tendon mechanics. Across all tendons, elastin degradation affected the elastic stress response by decreasing stress values while increasing the modulus gradient of the stress-strain curve. These data suggest that fascicular elastic fibers contribute to the tensile mechanical response of tendon, likely by regulating collagen engagement under load. At low strains, elastin seems to bear a significant portion of the load while the underlying collagen architecture uncrimps and reorganizes. Extrapolating to larger strains when the collagen becomes more fully engaged, the modulus of elastin-degraded tendon may match or even potentially exceed native tissue due to the increased modulus gradient of the stress-strain curve. 

In addition, this work leveraged a novel genetic mouse model of local elastin knockout to study the role of elastin on stress relaxation, ramp to failure, and fatigue mechanics for functionally distinct Achilles and tibialis anterior tendons. In ramp to failure mechanical testing, results exhibited tendon-specific effects with reduced elastin content. Furthermore, elastin knockdown led to increased strain during fatigue testing in energy-storing tendons but increased early hysteresis and decreased fatigue-life in both tendon types. Damage metrics showed opposite trends in collagen denaturation by tendon type, but consistent results for the accumulation of collagen kinking after fatigue loading. Results suggest that different mechanisms are responsible for each type of damage and that damage-mediating mechanisms of elastic fibers are tendon-type dependent. 

To broaden the impact of this work to the local community, several outreach activities with middle and high school students were pursued. As one example, details are provided here for a collaborative partnership that was established between the Biomedical Science Program at Pattonville High School, a St. Louis area school, and our research group at Washington University in St. Louis. The partnership developed three unique outreach/educational opportunities that were carried out on an annual basis: (1) a half-day visit of 12th-grade students to the university to visit three laboratories pursuing biomedical research, (2) presentation of a biomedical research showcase at the high school where doctoral graduate students presented a series of science demonstrations for 9th-12th grade students participating in the Biomedical Science Program, and (3) hosting of individual high school seniors at WashU to help them complete their capstone project directly in a university lab. Post-program surveys have shown that our outreach program is increasing interest in STEM within all ages of high school students. 

Conclusions from this work have advanced understanding of composition-dependent mechanics in tendon and will inform efforts to restore proper function in tendons with elastinopathic conditions or with degradation caused by overuse or age. Through this study, we also broadened impact within local communities by partnering with K-12 programs to provide unique educational opportunities to aspiring scientists/engineers.

 


Last Modified: 03/25/2025
Modified by: Spencer Lake
